title: Moving on Riemannian manifolds
body: Let $a,b,c\in\mathbb{R}^n$ such that $c$ is inside the $n$ -disk with $a$ and $b$ as south and north poles. Then as $c$ moves toward $a$ through the line segment joining $a$ and $c$ , $c$ is also moving away from $b$ (in terms of $d(b,c)$ ). Is there an analogy of the above statement on Riemannian manifolds? Say replace 'distance' by 'Riemannian metric' and replace 'line segment' by 'geodesics'? Or, in other words, fix any $a$ and $b$ on a Riemannian manifold, what is the set of points $c$ such that when $c$ moves to $a$ through geodesics, $c$ is moving away from $b$ ? On $\mathbb{R}^n$ we know the set contains all points $c$ such that $\angle acb$ is not acute. riemannian-geometry smooth-manifolds Share Cite Improve this question Follow edited Jul 13, 2020 at 18:12 asked Jul 13, 2020 at 6:34 ryanriess 219 1 1 gold badge 2 2 silver badges 5 5 bronze badges $\endgroup$ 5 1 $\begingroup$ Let your space be a line, $c=0,a=1,b=2$. When $c$ moves to $a$ through the line segment $[0,1]$, it is moving towards $b$. $\endgroup$ Alexandre Eremenko –  Alexandre Eremenko 2020-07-13 11:24:04 +00:00 Commented Jul 13, 2020 at 11:24 $\begingroup$ @AlexandreEremenko In this case $c$ is not inside the disk with $a$ and $b$ as south and north poles, where the disk is $[1,2]$. $\endgroup$ ryanriess –  ryanriess 2020-07-13 16:38:24 +00:00 Commented Jul 13, 2020 at 16:38 $\begingroup$ Then please explain what are the South and North poles for arbitrary Riemannian metric. $\endgroup$ Alexandre Eremenko –  Alexandre Eremenko 2020-07-13 17:36:30 +00:00 Commented Jul 13, 2020 at 17:36 $\begingroup$ @AlexandreEremenko I am not sure, and that is what I am wondering. Put it in another way, fix any $a$ and $b$ on a Riemannian manifold, what is the set of points $c$ such that when $c$ moves to $a$ through geodesics, $c$ is moving away from $b$? $\endgroup$ ryanriess –  ryanriess 2020-07-13 17:51:13 +00:00 Commented Jul 13, 2020 at 17:51 $\begingroup$ You are talking about the Dirichlet domain / Voronoi diagram of a pair of points.
